intro: Conyza aegyptiaca var. lineariloba, commonly known as the Egyptian gooseweed, is a flowering plant native to Africa, the Middle East, and parts of Asia. It is an annual herb that typically grows to a height of about 30–60 cm, featuring slender, linear leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. The plant produces small, white to pale yellow flowers arranged in a composite head, which are followed by fluffy, wind-dispersed seeds. It thrives in disturbed soils and is often found in fields, roadsides, and waste areas. Due to its rapid growth and adaptability, it can become invasive in certain regions.
